results.title: Memory of Moholy-Nagy
results.brief_description: An digitally animated journey through the abstract colors, compositions, and constructions of the Hungarian artist Laszlo Moholy-Nagy. Using 3D animation tools, the artist has created a landscape of the mind of this important 20th century artist.

results.title: Human motions
results.brief_description: Around 1987, Waliczky used an ATARI 520 ST to make Human Motions (or, Computer Mobiles) his first-ever animations. In these first seven works, Waliczky explored the possibility offered by the ATARI computer of storing and endlessly repeating a one to four seconds long animated sequence. The seven computer animated sequences are: “WHEEL”, “LOVE TRIANGLE”, CENTRAL SHUTTER”, “BALANCE”, WATERBIRD”, CRYING WOMAN”, “EYE”. The COMPUTER MOBILES address a number of major artistic and technical questions which are characteristic of Waliczky’s oeuvre and crop up repeatedly in subsequent works. Among these issues is the principle of colour animation, i.e., the use of changes in colour to create an impression of movement, as in the two mobiles WATERBIRD and CRYING WOMAN. In BALANCE, one of the most attractive works in the COMPUTER MOBILES series, Waliczky arranged the digitized photographs of a man and a woman into an endless vertical composition. The two figures, captured in acrobatic poses, seem to push and pull one another to and fro, as if engaged in a circus performance watched by the camera as it slowly pans upwards.

results.title: Is there any room for me here?
results.brief_description: This black-and-white computer animation is based around the image of a sparsely furnished apartment at nighttime, using light and shade effects - of a subtlety and delicacy that recalls the brushstrokes in a Chinese ink drawing - to pick out the objects from the dark background. The austere beauty of the forms and movements is accentuated by the strains of a Bach cello suite.

results.title: [Untitled]
results.brief_description:
“Untitled” is an interactive CD ROM that explores the changing view outside the window of its main character.

The use of black and white, and its simple graphic design add to the poignancy and impact of this innovative work.

“Untitled” presents a brooding, dark Beckett-like world of isolation and alienation. The characters appear disconnected from each other and dislocated from the world presented in the CD ROM.

results.title: The Hiding place
results.brief_description:
‘The Hiding place’ makes frightening Freudian references to Enid Blyton’s children’s story ‘The Magic faraway tree’. ‘The Hiding place’ examines the fraught relationship between siblings and their mother.

‘The Hiding place’s‘ use of Flash animation and faraway tree theme lulls the viewer into a comfort zone that quickly evaporates as the viewer explores the work. The work features advanced use of net based interactivity.

results.title: Basilisk
results.creator_credit: Lloyd Sharp, Panos Couros and Wayne Stamp
results.brief_description: ‘Basilisk’ is an interactive CD-Rom that operates as a conceptual journey into an ancient illustrated philosophical text and an imaginary bestiary. Through labryinthine visuals and language, ‘Basilisk’ charts a fiction of the genesis of the male as a queered perspective on subjectivity. As the artists state: “It derives its intensities from an alchemistry of mediaeval marvels and a bricolage of contemporary nomadic thought… Basilisk diagrams the multiple relations that converge upon a making of the male that is monstrous and virtual. As a queered perspective on subjectivity, it derives itself from a hybrid relation between the alchemistry of wonder and a wander in the fourfold thought of the subject in Felix Guattari’s philophical text ‘Chaosmosis’.”

results.title: reLOCATED - Mr and Mrs Kemp
results.brief_description: Kensington - this short film is created from a series of photographs and interviews with Mr and Mrs Kemp, residents of the Kensington Public Housing estate for 38 years. ‘reLOCATED’ documents the lives of residents from the estate who were moved when the estate was redeveloped. It is a visual record of how places contain the memories of people’s lives as well as a fantastic example of how you can use non-video media to make a powerful moving image story.

results.title: Carpark
results.brief_description: Moorabbin - The shopping mall is now a permanent fixture of our suburban landscapes. Carpark consists of multiple scenes of shopping, parking and just hanging-out juxtaposed against an aural collage of people talking about their experience of mall culture. This is a superbly crafted short experimental work that will resonate with each and every one of us who has spent time ‘down at the Mall’. Carpark was made over a weekend in the carpark of Southland shopping centre.

results.title: Stack
results.brief_description: In ‘Stack’, sound artist Ros Bandt captures sounds from the city stack emissions, a 55 metre chimney stack that extracts fumes from the Citylink tunnel. Sounds from the cylinder, the external grid and internal resonant surfaces, along with ambient sounds of the industrial extractor fans and builders working were recorded. Sections of the steel frame were electrified in order to generate original percussion timbres. The tunnel footage was shot and edited by Martin Wright.

results.title: 70 years at Brunswick Baths
results.brief_description: Brunswick - Harry Ivory, a fitness fanatic, a boxer, boxing trainer and local legend has been attending the Brunswick Baths since the day it opened in 1928. Part of a longer documentary about Harry’s life, this 4 minute film was made especially for the MAP project and focuses on the importance to him of the Brunswick Baths and the Baths community. Harry loves the place and often says it is the Baths that keep him going.
